description.text: Oye! Oye! Brenda the articulated battle tardigrade has been released into the wilds of 3D printing! Join the Horde to be among the first humanoids to learn about the next epic project from Zheng Labs! We now return you to your regular model description.

Seej is an Open-Source tabletop wargame based around 3D printing. This archive contains almost everything you need to start playing Seej. You'll need to supply your own pennies and elastic bands. Rules for Seej are at http://www.s33j.net Keep it friendly. Show no mercy. Playing Seej with a group? Register your clan and find local players at The Obelisk!
This is the 2012 Seej Starter Set. It's since been updated. Check out the 2013 Starter Set: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:116450
And it's been updated again! Here's the 2015 version.

This set contains: one Zheng3 Penny Catapult: single-STL and broken-out.
a Seej Battle Flag
a Seej Battle Flag, Pennon
a Bloxen, Basic
a Bloxen, Cobblestone The models are cleaned up and a little more efficient than their singular counterparts available elsewhere on Thingiverse. Basic Flag and Basic Bloxen are included for thoroughness, but most players will opt for playing with the more stylish Pennon and Cobblestone Bloxen. Print one set for each player. Acquire pennies for ammunition, read the rules at http://www.s33j.net, and start playing! Non-U.S. SeejmÃƒÂ¦sters can print the catapult in pieces and rescale the throwing arm to accomodate their local coinage. Many players quickly upgrade to a new Seej engine like the Zheng3 Penny Ballista or one of its derivatives: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23464

description.text: This is a modified version of mattschoenholz's "Easy adjustable Rostock/Kossel J-Head Mount". After printing mattschoenholz's version I realized that the holes did not line up with the standard Rostock platform and that it seemed to use M2.5 hardware instead of the M3 indicated in the instructions. This version has been updated to use the dimensions for the standard Rostock platform, M3 hardware, some minor tweaks to make it more printable, and updated the code to make it customizable. The STLs that have been generated are for the standard Rostock platform and 1/8" NPT (or BSP) pneumatic fittings. Also, please note, this version is not compatible with the original design. 25-Feb-2014 Update After some use, I've found that this mount was unnecessarily complicated, made wiring difficult, and reduced the overall printable height. Please see my simplified and improved design here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:253859.

author: vmllr

description.text:
This is an assembly to hold led brake/reverse lights on an old r/v. It was measured to fit a 1974 Argosy, but will most likely fit other years and Airstreams as well. You have to remove the gaudy light box on the rear to install these. It fits the 4" round led brake/turn and the 4" led reverse lights that you can find online.

The back of the assembly is curved to match the radius of the body on the rv. You'll have to figure out how you want to mount them, I'm making an access panel inside and using screws to attach them.

For those of you with gargantuan printers, you can use the solid piece. Otherwise, I have split it into 3 pieces to fit. All the parts are perfectly symmetrical, so you don't need to mirror any of the parts.

I have also included a cylinder of the required 102.5mm for the light assembly. That helps for those unfortunate souls who need to epoxy the split parts together. You'll need to print 4 of those.
I measured the trailer carefully, used freecad to mock up the radius, and designed it in Openscad. The wings in between have a raised outline of a stormtrooper and a hippo, because my boys like them.

description.text: A 3d model of SCP-184 that is based off of "SCP-184" by "Dr Gears" http://www.scp-wiki.net/scp-184

print_settings.Notes:: To get this to print on the Mini you have to rotate it to standing and then put it diagonally across the plate. Make sure to use supports for the main face, but you can change your x/y support min. so that it doesn't create supports for the smaller holes. I printed it with 75% infill and 4 walls (1.6mm) and the thing feels super solid. Also, you can only print one bracket at a time, but you can include 2 of the thumbscrew parts on the plate with each bracket. Make sure to flip the thumbscrew part so the inset for the nut is on the top.

title: Cheapus Maximus - Printed bed extension for the Monoprice Select Mini (MPSM)

description.text:
UPDATE 6/30/17- Made a few more minor adjustments, including altering the design slightly so that if you set your build plate size to 125x125 (the mini can handle it!) then you can plate both brackets and all the thumb screws in a single print. Added full plate STL.

UPDATE 6/29/17- made minor adjustments to the front and back bracket after yet another test fitting. We are getting close folks..

UPDATE: After printing out the brackets and messing around with them, I decided to make a couple of changes including... drum roll... thumb screws for the leveling screws so you can level it by hand with no allen wrench! This slightly changes the BOM, you no longer need the M3 Hex nuts, but will need 4 more square nuts and you will need to print four of the thumbscrew part.

WARNING: This thing has gone through multiple iterations and tests, but just as I was about to finish with what I am hoping is either the final version, or close to it, I have had a plethora of printer problems (all non-related to the project). This is essentially a beta-version that I am posting so that my comrades over at the MP Mini FB page (https://www.facebook.com/groups/1717306548519045) could have a whack at it while I am still working on it. If you make one, please let me know how it goes, I would love feedback and I am more than willing to make design changes (there will almost undoubtedly be design changes). I am also working on designing a partially printed bed extension carriage that uses some cheap aluminum L stock from home depot and I will link to that project once it is closer to ready. The links in the BOM are just for reference, but I would highly recommend https://www.trimcraftaviationrc.com, they are my go to for high quality and cheap hardware and they usually take only 1-2 business days for me to have my parts in hand. All told the parts can be obtained for around 15$ US.

BOM:
Front Bracket
Back Bracket
4x Thumbscrew part

2- 8mm x 300mm Linear Shafts (http://www.ebay.com/itm/8mm-x-300mm-Cylinder-Liner-Rail-Linear-Shaft-Optical-Axis-Good-Wear-Resistance-/172547455818?hash=item282ca13b4a:g:TyoAAOSw2gxYsAHA)

12- M3 square nuts (https://www.trimcraftaviationrc.com/index.php?route=product/product&path=77&product_id=549)

4- M3 hex nuts (https://www.trimcraftaviationrc.com/index.php?route=product/product&path=14_35&product_id=133)

8- M3x14mm Socket Head Cap Screw (https://www.trimcraftaviationrc.com/index.php?route=product/product&path=24_18_37&product_id=190)

4- M3x20mm Flat Socket Countersunk Screw (https://www.trimcraftaviationrc.com/index.php?route=product/product&path=24_3&product_id=350)

GT2 belt at least 350mm long (http://www.ebay.com/itm/3D-Printer-GT2-Timing-Belt-1M-Length-2mm-Pitch-6mm-Width-ABS-For-Reprap-Mendel-/292137200256?hash=item4404bbea80:g:gtcAAOSw~y9ZMGnI)

New Glass to cut longer bed (http://www.homedepot.com/p/8-in-x-10-in-x-125-in-Clear-Glass-90810/202091040)

To assemble begin by disconnecting your bed heater and thermistor wires from the mainboard. Next disconnect the belt by removing the tension spring and then carefully clipping one of the zipties holding the belt on. Pull off the carriage and bed by unscrewing them. Leave the 8mm rods in place, and using your new 300mm rods push the old ones out of the linear bearings so there is no gap and no chance that any of the ball bearings can fall out. Once the new rods are in put the two brackets on either end of the rods. The brackets are almost identical except for the placement of the belt attachment so make sure to keep track of which is the front and which is the back. Press the brackets onto the rods (it helps to dry fit all of this before installing it). Put a square nut into each of the square holes on the face of each bracket (there are 4 on each bracket) and then insert the m3x14mm socket cap screws into the holes on the sides and inside of the bracket faces to go into the square nuts and put tension on the rods. Don't tighten those screws until you get the printer bed and fit it to the bracket using the pre-existing springs and the m3X20mm flat socket countersunk screws. Put m3 hex nuts into the spots on the bracket you want to use and then install the bed onto the brackets. Once the bed is on and the screws through the springs look straight and everything looks nice and square, tighten the bolts on the sides of the linear rods to lock them into place. Install the new belt in the same way it was on the old carriage and use the spring tensioner (i like it on the back, but I could be wrong). Once the brackets are on, push the bed around to make sure the belt is on correctly and the bed can move easily. You are going to have to figure out a good way to hook up the bed heater, I am personally only going to use the bed extension to print PLA and material that doesn't need the heater so that there is less risk of wire fatigue and less of a chance of the printed bed carriage warping or failing. Once everything is on and moving freely, push the bed all the way to the back making sure it engages the y-limit switch. Mark the position of the nozzle and and then move the bed all the way forward (making sure its not hitting anything in the back) and then measure the distance between the two marks, and that's your new print bed size! I haven't figured out a good way to notch a glass bed, so right now I am using a 110mm x 200mm piece of glass that fits between the bed level screws.I recently improved the design to use thumbscrew for the bed level screws, so now you can put glass right over the top of the level screws and ratchet them from the bottom! whoot! You will need to put some super glue/thred locker/jb weld on the heads of the bed level screws to fix them inplace so the thumbscrews will work. So there you go. Please leave comments and feedback on ways this can be improved and if you have a mini check out the fb page above, I am pretty much constantly lurking there along with some pretty epic folks who are maxing their mini's like nobodies business!

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

75%

Notes:

To get this to print on the Mini you have to rotate it to standing and then put it diagonally across the plate. Make sure to use supports for the main face, but you can change your x/y support min. so that it doesn't create supports for the smaller holes. I printed it with 75% infill and 4 walls (1.6mm) and the thing feels super solid. Also, you can only print one bracket at a time, but you can include 2 of the thumbscrew parts on the plate with each bracket. Make sure to flip the thumbscrew part so the inset for the nut is on the top.

comments.text: Hi! The pictures so far don't accurately represent the point of the project. So the goal is to still use as much of the stock machine as possible with the least parts/materials that need to be bought. So at least with my home depot glass pane that cost like 2$ it has been rigid enough to overlap the stock bed by at least 50mm with little to no sagging. The issue with the thumb screws is that with apiece of glass of lapping the edges makes accessing the heads of the level screws hard, so in the new design you just put the glass over the tops of the screws and then on the bottom of the carriage there are the thumb screws that the bed level screws go into. That way you can level the bed with no tools and without having to cut the glass weird or something. This mod will require either a z switch spacer or the epic adjustable z switch mod.

comments.text: That is one of my design goals, to not mess up the stock bed. just set aside the original rods, carriage and belt. The pieces you are reusing for this mod aren't being altered just used in the same capacity they were before. Just in designing this thing I have pulled the printer apart, fit the mod and then reassembled it to stock probably 5 times.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Designed this cake stand for my wife for her birthday with slots for ribbon.

Print the top top side down and the base right side up. The parts go together easily but fit nice and snug so you shouldn't need glue or anything.

If you can do variable layer heights (e.g., Slic3r Prusa Edition) then it's worth increasing the resolution of the shallow angle parts of the base to avoid obvious steps. That, or just print it at 0.1/0.05.

The top should be fine in 0.2mm and is pretty sturdy.

description.text:
French Description Below.

This is one of my proposal for the MyMiniFactory Handspinner contest : https://www.myminifactory.com/fr/competition/tinkercad-competition-110

This design was made to fit with 22x8mm Spinner ball bearings (8mm of internal diameter). It is made to work with 5 bearings.

I printed it with PLA, at 20% infill, with a resolution of 0.2mm height, 2 shells and no raft nor support.
This object was made in Tinkercad. https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7raSTLZfwnN

Ce design a été conçu pour le concours MyMiniFactory sur les Handspinners : https://www.myminifactory.com/fr/competition/tinkercad-competition-110.
Ce design est conçu pour fonctionner avec des roulements à billes de 22x8 mm (Diamètre interieur de 8mm) et fonctionne avec 5 roulements à billes.

Je l'ai imprimé avec du PLA avec les paramètres suivants : 20% infill, 2 shells, 0.2mm de résolution.

Détail de l'impression

Infill : from 20 to 50%

Shells : At least 2

Resolution : 0.2mm

I didn't need raft nor support.
It has some weakpoints (DNA joints), but it should resists for many hours using them (So far so good for the one I printed at the moment).

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
This is an MCP brace for hypermobility in the first knuckle of the fingers.

Video explanation: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ObN70mUm4xo

I made these because I tend to hyperextend my fingers while typing. It doesn't hurt to do this once or twice, but after several hours of typing my hands can become pretty sore. This brace prevents fingers from hyperextending but does not limit normal range of motion. Similar braces must usually be custom ordered, and cost between $80-150 each without insurance. When 3d printed, these cost about 2 cents each. It's a fast print, and after a couple days of use my joint pain is basically gone!

Since I made these for myself, I have included sizes that tend to fit my hands. The included sizes are:

  • 4
  • 5
  • 6
  • 7
  • 7.5
  • 8
  • 8.5
  • 9
  • 10

The models can be changed according to your needs pretty easily in Tinkercad. I have included a link to my model below. The long loop goes on the top of your hand, and the short loop goes on your palm. The longest loop should be long enough to go around your knuckle. The shorter loop should be short enough to allow your hand to close normally. A digital caliper will be very useful for taking these measurements.

This is the first 3d thing I have modeled and used. Constructive criticism is very much welcome.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/a0GNpCoEYR1

Other useful designs:

Ring sizer:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:318876

Flexy splint for other finger joints:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1055457

In the future I plan to have a generator available to create any size ring on demand.

In the meantime, here is a list of ring sizes. Provided sizes are US ring sizes.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ring_size

For my card games, I always put me cards into sleeves. Sometimes card game companies will give you enough room in the box for this... others don't. Sadly this was true with the game Dragonwood by Gamewright. So I tossed out the cheap black plastic holder and made my own. It will fit all of the cards (Sleeved or not) and your dice.

NOTE:
This is a big print, it took me about 12 hours and 32 meters/ 247 grams of filament to print. The one in the photo is the original design, I have since revised it to fit the dice better and made the finger holes bigger so it is easier to get the cards and dice out.
I assume this will work in other boxes, or just as a general holder, so the dimensions of the print in below in case you are wondering.

Dimensions: 152.40 x 190.5 x 45.80

title: Tronxy X1 part cooling fan shroud

description.text:
For radial fan BD125015MB 50x50x15mm.
Bolts directly to the M3 threads at the side of the extruder cover. One hole of the fanmount is 1-2mm off or so, need to do a little update later. But works also with only one bolt.

Fan (just red & black wire) just needs to be connected to the "FAN" port of the Melzi board and it works right away with the settings from the slicer (firmware already configured).

ATTENTION - VERY POWERFUL! ;-)
My experience: Use max. 80% fan speed or insulate your heater block (eg with a bit of stone wool and kapton tape). Otherwise it will cool down your hotend too much and you get underextrusion.

description.text:
This is a bracket I designed to mount this thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:209423 by Mak-A-Face to my MakerFarm Prusa I3 8". I liked that duct because it was a nice tight fit to the J-head and tightly directs air across the cooling fins only. You could probably use this bracket/shroud combination on any Wade extruder on a Prusa I3. Vitamins List
1 25mm M3 Socket Head Cap Screw
6 12mm M3 Socket Head Cap Screws
1 M3 Plain Nut
40mm Fan

1-Mount the M3 nut into the nut capture on the bracket.
2-Screw the bracket on to the shroud
3-Mount your fan
4-Screw the assembly on to your extruder
5- Wire it up and enjoy PLA fun with your J-Head.

print_settings.Notes:: RPi

description.text:
The Prusa i3 MK2S is a great printer especially for the hobbyist or light industrial desktop user. That having been said it is a raw printer without a lot of accessories that would make it a great printer. The is the forth in a series of accessories that I designed for the i3. The others are:

  • Enclosure
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2396990
  • HEPA Filter
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2394452
  • Spool Holder
    https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2398480

The Prusa i3 MK2S printer's primary input is via a standard sized SD card. The card supplied with the printer contains a number of utilities and sample prints but the logistics of moving designs to the printer is cumbersome at best particularly if the printer and the workstation are not close by. Also provided is a standard USB Printer Port that can be connected to a print server.

Although full size PC's can be used to host a print server, there reliability as a print server is less than desirable unless they are dedicated to that task. A better solution is to use a small but powerful computer on a chip board such as the Raspberry Pi (RPi). The Raspberry Pi Zero W contains all the necessary interface to provide wireless print serving along with a camera interface which supports a low cost 1080P pin hole camera.

This design includes an Uninterruptible Power Supply (UPS) for the RPi. While this is not absolutely necessary, it is good practice with Linux based computers. Much like Windows, Linux can corrupt files if not properly shut down before power is removed. The UPS has enough capacity to operate for several hours after power is interrupted. This is very useful in areas prone to power outages that would otherwise destroy long print runs. At idle the OctoPrint Server consumes 0.230 Amps. During the average print run OctoPrint draws 0.350 amps. Peak consumption (0.450 amps) occurs during Time Lapse Movie generation at the end of the print run.

An alternative to using an on-board UPS would be to use an external unit.

OctoPrint (OctoPrint.org) is a free Linux based print server designed for the Raspberry Pi computer, among other platforms, and is licensed under the Affero General Public License. The latest version can be downloaded and executed on the Raspberry Pi Zero W without modification. See the OctoPrint.org site for details on downloading and setup.

Note:
Be sure to order the Raspberry Pi Zero W and not the Raspberry Pi Zero. The "W" version includes a high speed WiFi adapter which obviates the need for a USB Bridge and External WiFi adapter.

Warning:
This design requires the builder to have some soldering capabilities and skills. Please review the construction steps carefully before proceeding.

Printer:

Prusa i3 MK2S

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.20

Infill:

25%

Notes:

There are a number of horizontal slots in the vertical sides of the RPi case that are 10mm or more in length. The Prusa i3 handles this with minimal sags on the 1st layer over the void but some printers produce unacceptable results due largely to lack of extruded filament cooling. If you have difficulties printing the case, turn on supports.

Step 1: Print the Raspberry Pi Zero Case and Camera Mount

This is fairly straight forward and requires no support structures if printed on a 3D printer that can handle 10mm overhangs.

Trim off any extraneous extrusions that may have occurred during the print process.

NOTE:
The Case Top is a pressure fit to the Case Bottom and requires no hardware. The same is true of the RPi Camera enclosure. Hardware is required to mount the Raspberry Pi Zero W and the Geekworm UPS Hat to the Case Bottom, and the Camera Mount to print bed.

Step 2: Prepare the Raspberry Pi Zero W

Solder the 40 Pin Header Connector to the underside of the Raspberry Pi Zero W. This is opposite the conventional way the connector is installed and is necessary to allow the battery to be positioned between the RPi and the UPS boards.

Care should be taken not to bridge solder between pins on the RPi board. See area circled below:

Raspberry Pi Header Connector Detail Step 3: Install the RPi onto the UPS Board

Carefully install the RPi board onto the pins of the UPS Board. Visually inspect the connections to Insure all 40 pins are inserted into their respective socket on the RPi. It is easy to install the boards off one row or one column.

Step 4: Install Battery

Position Battery between the RPi and UPS boards as depicted below. Insert the Battery Connector into the socket on the UPS board as indicated.

If the RPi is powered up when the battery is connected Press the On/Off switch for approximately 0.5 seconds. Holding the On/Off button longer than 1 second will power the UPS and RPi on again.

UPS ON/OFF and Battery Connection Step 5: Prepare Control Box Bottom for Electronics

Insert a M3x10 Counter Sunk Flat Head screw into the Control Box as indicated. Insure that the screw will freely move in and out. This screw will be positioned against the UPS On/Off button and will afford control over the UPS once the electronics are installed.

On/Off Plunger Detail Step 6: Install Electronics

Hold the Plunger Screw inserted above tight against the inside of the Control Box and slide the Electronics assembly, built up in the previous steps, into the Control Box left side first so as to engage the Plunger against the *On/Off button.

Ease the Electronics right side into the Control Box such that the entire assembly is fully bottomed out against the bosses built into the Control Box.

Secure the electronics with two M2.5x20 Cap Head Screws as shown below.

Attach the Camera Zero Insertion Pressure (ZIP) ribbon cable into the slot provided on the RPi board. It is necessary to first release the jamb strip on the top outside edge of the connector. After inserting the ribbon cable this strip must be pushed back to its original position in order to secure the ribbon cable in place. Lightly pull on the Ribbon Cable. If properly installed it will not come out of the connector. See below.

Electronics Case Detail Step 7: Mount Electronics Control Box and Attach Cables

Install the Control Box onto the Left Hand i3 Frame Threaded Rod using 3 Cable Ties as indicated below. Tighten Cable Ties as much as practicable to prevent the Control Box from rotating on the Threaded Rod when the printer is moved.

Install the Printer cable into the USB connector on the RPi as indicated below. Attach the other end to the printer in the port provided.

Install the USB power cable into the UPS as indicated below.

Install the Micro SD card containing the Octoprint previously download from the OctoPrint.org site (http://octoprint.org)

Install the top Control Box Cover by pressing it in place. No hardware is required to secure the cover.

Note:
The RPi gains power from the UPS via the 40 Pin GPIO connector. The RPi PWR USB port is not connected in this design.

The UPS Battery charge state is indicated by the four LEDs shown below. Each LED represents 25% charge level (e.g. 3 LEDs - 75% charge). These lights are visable through corresponding holes in the left Control Box side.

A single greed CPU Run LED is visible at the right side of the Camera cable opening.

Step 8: Install Camera Mount

Install Camera Mount onto the bottom left hand forward Build Plate screw using M3x12 Cap Screw. Position the mount as fully engaged with the build plate frame as possible while insuring clearance with all other printer features. See right hand picture below.

Note:
The Camera Mount must clear the Cable Tie holding the LH linear Rod to the printer frame.

Camera Mount to Printer Detail Step 9: Mount Camera

install the Camera Cable into the Camera Module in like manner to above. Place the Camera Module into the Camera Case and snap the Camera Case top into the base insuring the camera module is properly and securely positioned and held in place. The top is designed to be an interference fit and should not fall off without being pried loose. See below:

Bend the ribbon cable around the top and down the back leaving about 10mm loop to act as a strain relief. Secure the ribbon cable to the back of the Camera Case using double sided tape. See below.

Camera Case Detail Step 10: Install Camera

Install the Camera Case on the Camera Mount as indicated below. Point the camera in the general direction of the build place. Fine Tuning can be accomplished using the Time Lapse setup wizard in the Octoprint application.

Camera Installation & Cable Detail Step 11: Configure OctoPrint

Configure the OctoPrint application via a browser at Octopi.local

OctoPrint configuration Main Menu Print a Test Case

Below is a short time lapse video how the build of the Top Print Server Case:

OctoPrint Case Time Lapse

Bill on Materials
  • Case - top & Bottom (Print this Thing)
  • Camera Mount (Included in Thing)
  • Raspberry Pi Zero W (includes Power Supply & Standard Case)
    https://www.amazon.com/CanaKit-Raspberry-Wireless-Official-Supply/dp/B071L2ZQZX
  • Raspi UPS HAT Board for Raspberry Pi Zero and 2500mAh Lithium Battery
    https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01MQYX4UX
  • Raspberry Pi Camera
    https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01ER2SKFS
  • Raspberry Pi Camera Cable for Pi Zero
    https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01LY2V23F
  • Left Angled 90 Degree Micro USB OTG to Standard B Type Printer Cable
    https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B06XXL8T45
  • 2.54mm 2x20 40-Pin Female Pin Header Socket Connector
    https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00R1LLM1M
  • 32GB microSDHC Card with Adapter-UHS-I, U3 - up to 90MB/sec
    https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01G26R13Y
  • 2 ea M2.5x20mm Pitch Bolts Hex Socket Cap Head Screws
    https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B011BNXFTW
  • 1ea Flat Head, M3x10mm Screw
    https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B005DS4UR8

comments.text: Haven't made this yet, but I believe I will as it's the best design I've seen. But a quick question ;  the raspberry pi connects to the printer port on the Prusa ? I was thinking a USB port. Thanks !
comments.author: stbw_9238

comments.text: The connection is via a standard USB printer cable.  The USB end of the cable is plugged into the RPi USB port while the square end of the cable is plugged into the Prusa control board.  The printer port is located on the top of the control box cover.
comments.author: stbw_9238

comments.text: I'm on it  ! Thanks !
comments.author: jmillerfo

comments.text: :clap: :clap: :clap: awesome project and explanation!! Thanks for taking the time to write out all of the details. It's appreciated :)
comments.author: cschmitz81

comments.text: Your Welcome
comments.author: cschmitz81

comments.text: Is the RPi ZeroW powerful enough for more detailed prints? I found that my RPi3 sometimes has some problems keeping up with prints that have a too large gcode
comments.author: FlipFlop94

comments.text: Generally it is.  I have found that rebooting the RPi just before a large print job improves the performance.  That having been said I have noticed print jobs where there is a lot of small draws, print speeds have to be reduced to prevent the printer from hesitating ever so slightly.  Long straight or large arcs perform fine.  Both the RPi ZeroW and the RPi 3 seem to perform the same.  A large 3 hour print job finishes within minutes of each other.  I am not sure whether it is the speed of the IO or the processor that causes these small hesitations.  One final observation: The speed and size of the Mini SD card can have a huge impact on OctoPi performance.  I always use the fasted card I can get but in no case < 80MB/sec rating.
comments.author: FlipFlop94

comments.text:
Both RPi3 ZeroW and RPi3 seem to perform the same...? Since the RPi3 has more ram I suppose that something else causes the hesitations? Ill check my SD cards as well, but generally, with my RPi3 I use high quality SDcards (not sure what writing speed actually).
Thanks for the info anyway! :)

From Vention's 3D catalog. I've uploaded the 45mm extrusions.
Vention is a Canadian company offering an online 3D platform for designing, building and ordering industrial equipment. They offer a fast turnaround for heavy assemblies, parts and systems. https://www.vention.io/

I have downloaded in STEP format, imported into Orchard, disassembled and fused the parts then saved as STL. I separated the pin and bushing.

You've heard of fidget spinners. Everyone has. You might have realized that fidgets have expanded into all kinds of toys and across the globe.

Welcome to the "Fidget Boomerang", my own design. I have optimized this design for aerodynamics, speed, and stability. You might want to scale the design to about an inch across.

UPDATE: I like this design and worked on it...made a few adjustments. Added a new STL file (earbud reel V2.stl). This new one has the same outside dimensions but has more volume for cable storage. Looks and feels better too, imho.

ADDED a modified version: -->earbud reel V2.stl I searched but didn't see a design like this. If there is one on Thingiverse, then credit to that person. These JVC buds have a 2mm (2.2mm ?) cord and are about 1.2 meters (48 inches) long .
The buds go in the center, then wrap the cord and tuck the end connector into the nearest slot. With Afinia default settings (0.30mm layers, medium speed, with a raft) it's near a 45 minute print and uses 25g ABS. The finished part weighs ~15g. Angled long-nose pliers were helpful in removing all the support from the center cavity. Note: I use Imperial measurements and my STL files could appear tiny (3 inches may equate to 3 cm) when viewed . While some metric-mode editing software might require setting adjustments, AFAIK print software recognizes the situation and prints them correctly.
[EDIT 3-2015]
If your print software imports it really tiny, scale up by a factor of 25.4 to get the proper (metric) dimensions. One of these days, I have to go through all my projects, create and upload metric versions...
Yeah.. like that will ever happen!
But seriously, that's what I do to create them. Just scale up by a factor of 25.4.

comments.text: Does the V2 make require any special build params? ie - supports, etc.  How well does that overhang print?
comments.author: JacksonDog

comments.text:
My Afinia printer's default settings (0.3mm layers, medium speed) worked well. This software puts significant support under virtually all overhangs. Thanks to that, overhang print quality is the same as elsewhere.
And when everything's working right, support detaches very easily, so I make no effort to minimize it except in special circumstances.

description.text:
These parts create legs for Keithley 2xxx instruments. They are similar to the 2000-BENCHKIT part, although these don't have rubber feet, nor do they have a handle.

I'm using it with a 2304A

They are designed to align with medium-aged HP/Agilent equipment, like the 66309D, which have a slot towards the front on their top.

To mount them, a pair of #6-32 x 1/2" bolts and a pair of #8-32 x 1/2" bolts are required. I also suggest using flat washers. I used four metric #5 washers.

The rear legs are symmetric.

For the front legs, a mirror image has to be printed. I used the mirror option in the slicer software.

For the front legs, a mirror image has to be printed. I used the mirror option in the slicer software.

There was no need for internal supports in the screw holes. I only used build-plate supports.
This model was designed using FreeCAD, and measurements of a Keithley 2304A and an Agilent 66309D.

author: Klunker77

remixed_from.author: karltinsly
remixed_from.title: Parts for Adding Third Z Screw to D-Bot

title: modified two-bearing Z mount for three-leadscrew Z axis system for D-bot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This refers to the 3-leadscrew Z axis solution originally posted by karltinsly.

I was unsatisifed with the use of a single, unflanged 608 (skateboard) bearing held by a plastic box to the underside of a modified Z motor mount. I felt that the leadscrew would not be supported enough against forces acting to tilt it from side to side. I also wanted a solution which left the face of the bearing flush with the other surfaces of the mount, in order to make it easier to find locking or clamping 8mm collars to secure the leadscrew with.

I started with the original D-bot Z axis motor mount, as Karl did, and modified it to hold the flanged version of the 608 bearings. I thickened the plate where the Z stepper was originally to be mounted to 7mm to match the thickness of the 608 bearings. I made the center hole the same 22mm width of the unflanged portion of the 608 bearing, and added a step for the flange itself.

I provide a matching 7mm thick block with the same M3 screw holes to hold a 2nd flanged 608 bearing, and a 21mm thick spacer to sandwich in between the Z mount and the second bearing block, that also pins the flanges of the bearings and holds them in place.

The whole sandwich is held together with four 40mm M3 bolts, with a washer at each end, and an M3 lock nut.

The result is a mount which is installed on a D-bot just like the original Z-axis stepper motor mounts. A 500mm long 8mm leadscrew is secured to these bearing blocks using whatever 8mm clamping or locking collar you find that will fit appropriately against the inner rim of the bearing.

I refer you to Karltinsly's original Thing, as well as Digger60's parts list for the pulleys and so forth, and KIdz's remixed Z axis belt tensioner.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2255835
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2179222

The parts specific to this dual-bearing Z axis leadscrew mount are:

F608-ZZ ball bearings (flanged version of the popular 608 skateboard bearing):
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01EM32W42/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

I intend to use the following 8mm clamping collars to secure the bottom of the leadscrew against the lower bearing of this mount block:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0063KPT16/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

A cheaper but perhaps a little dodgier solution using a single grub screw would be something like this:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0063KWI42/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1

I will need a spacer, either printed or metal, between the pulley wheel and the top bearing of this mount block. I have to figure out what height of spacer will put the pulley wheel at the same height as the pulley on the stepper motor using KIdz's pulley assembly.

I printed the three pieces per assembly of this thing out of PETG. The settings I used aren't required, though I think they are appropriate. As a 3D printing enthusiast I assume that anyone using these files can make their own best judgment as to the appropriate settings to use.

I printed the Z mount at 98% infill and 3 perimeters using a .4mm nozzle, using PETG at 260/70 C nozzle and bed temps, on PEI sheet with no further substance required for sticking it to the bed. This is essentially a solid part, as it needs to be stiff and strong.

I printed the 21mm spacer at 20% infill using PETG at 260/70 C temps, on PEI, using 4 perimeters. This part can be mostly air because it only must resist a crushing load between the four mounting screws, which will be well supported between the 4 perimeter outline and the 4 perimeters around each hole.

The 7mm end cap was printed at 98% infill using the same settings as the Z mount. I wanted it tough and strong, but honesty it could have used 4 perimeters and probably a sparse infill like the spacer and been good enough, if you think about what loads it is under.

I include the Solidworks 2016 sources along with the STL files. The STL for the modified Z motor mount was remixed from DSpauda's original Dbot file in a multi-step process using Tinkercad to modify the mount and then combine it with my 7mm thick plate that has the screw holes and the cavity for the flanged bearing.

NOTE: in order to keep my alignments and so forth nice and tight I use tight tolerances with these designs. You may find it necessary to chase the screw holes with a 3mm drill bit, or lightly deburr the cavities for the flanged 608 bearings with an Xacto knife, or else things may go in only with some muscle.

comments.text: Hi. just a question about the leadscrew.. did you just use the grub screw from the pulley hold into the threaded area or did you get leadscrew with a turndown smooth section?
comments.author: jtktam

comments.text: The grub screw from the pulley is currently just tightened against the coarse threads of the leadscrew. It's been fine so far. I did put a little blue loctite onto the grub screw, and tightened it as much as I dared without risking rounding it out. I didn't file a flat spot onto the leadscrew threads for the grub screw to sit against, but that would probably be a good idea.
comments.author: jtktam

comments.text:
I'm in the process of printing this upgrade to my D-Bot, how long timing belt did you use?
I like the slight overkill feeling of 98% infill, PETG and dual flanged bearings. I'm only printing in PLA but should be strong enough until I have my printer rigid and ready enough. Maybe I'll reprint them in PETG later on and modified for the 2040 profiles in my frame base.
comments.author: faekie

comments.text: Looks like marvelous overkill to me.
comments.author: mntbighker

comments.text: It might well be. Whether it's strictly necessary to have two separate bearings to support each leadscrew or not, the way I use the flanged bearings gives me two bearing sides that are flush with the mount, which makes it very easy to use the locking collars to hold the leadscrews securely. I've had these leadscrews installed for several weeks now, and this setup works great. The leadscrews lined up nice and vertical with the sides of my build platform, so alignment was easy. The whole system is vastly more stable than my stock 2 screw/2 stepper setup.
comments.author: mntbighker

comments.text: Nice improvement on my original design - which was, admittedly, just thrown together. I like the use of the flanged bearing to lock it in place. I agree with MKSA about one bearing being enough, though. Good job!
comments.author: karltinsly

comments.text: Thanks! And thanks for your original design!
comments.author: karltinsly

comments.text: One bearing is enough. You don't gain anything with two, but complicate the alignment. Luckily you use plastic that will give and therefore compensate any misalignment.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: I've got the three dual-bearing assemblies built and installed on my D-bot. I added photos to this item entry showing the installation. The alignment wasn't difficult. It helps that my leadscrews came from China nice and perfectly straight. I don't know if the PETG bearing assemblies are just flexing a little as you say, or if they naturally held the leadscrews straight up and down as they are designed to do, but the alignment was fine and the whole 3-screw Z axis is working very well indeed.
comments.author: MKSA

title: Tevo Black Widow Spool holder no hardware needed

description.text:
This Spool holder is designed to hang 1kg spools with no mounting hardware needed and the profile hooks into the channel of the Black Widow frame while the weight over the back holds it in place.

They are designed to take 16mm dowel or you could print your own 16mm x 60mm interlocking shafts to suit the length you need.

These can also be configured to take any thickness spool I've come across by making longer or shorter shafts.

Printer:

Tevo Black Widow

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

description.text:
Make your own unique one-of-a-kind flowers with this openSCAD file! Print beautiful flowers as a gift for that special someone, or just to help decorate your world. They print fast and easy (see instructions). Get creative and incorporate flowers into other models or for fashion (see picture of the tie jewelry).
The possibilities are HUGE - I have just scratched the surface and will upload my 9 favorite flowers (see "Makes" for notes on the settings).
I am exploring deliberately making drooloops, (I made that word up, droop+loop) and trying to harness the neat shapes you can get. This is my first attempt at something neat.
Please let me know how your prints turn out and post pics.
More drooloop objects:
jellyfish
experimental wide petal flower
drop printing vase Oh and if you like the black vase in my picts, i made with using PaulM's Customisable Spirograph Vase Generator
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53916

These are really fun to design and print. Each print job is fun since there's a slight element of randomness. The randomness is because we are deliberately "printing in the air" to create the "drooloops" (droop+loop) that make these flowers look so amazing.
These slicer settings worked with 3 different printers I tried, and I bet will work with any slicers/printer if you use the models I have uploaded, or any customizer you make if you don't change settings on the advance tab of the customizer version.
ALL UNITS millimeters (mm)
layer_height = 0.2
wall_thickness = 0.8
solid_layer_thickness = 0.6
fill_density = 0
support = None
platform_adhesion = None
solid_top = False (extra NOTE about solid_top: This is probably not your default setting....I use this so it will be hollow on top....for the pipe stem cleaner. I did not print the top, so this setting is kinda important to duplicate my results)
solid_bottom = True
Feel free to experiment and let everyone know if you find improvements or just interesting results. One person's "interesting results" may be another person's "that exactly what I was looking for!".
I was able to get these to print fine on the three different machine I have access to (Ultimaker1, MakerGear M2, and Type!Machines Series 1), but I bet you can get these out of any machine that is out there.
I will now go into gory details below. I learned a lot during this process and would like to share a few simple rules of thumb I use for the results I am getting, but I think all results look cool.
****(feel free to ignore everything below this line)****
Notes...about what I am doing to get more reliable and symmetrical results. If people think it would help, then I would also be happy to make some videos too.
NOTE ABOUT SLICER SETTINGS -(my 1st choice for slicing is CURA -it's free, slices better than anything I have used and works with everything as far as I can tell) SO for a good clean drooloop you want the petals to print with no in-fill (see pictures). I like a simple drooloop to be formed by the nozzle leaving the center and coming back in a straight line and extruding the whole time (no retractions, or crazy infill motions). Look at your nozzle paths before you print to check this. If your slicer does not let you do this, then get one of the gcode viewers out there. I like hudborg's GCode Analyzer/Visualizer - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:35248
You can control the nozzle path and get these results by choosing model dimensions and slicer settings that compliment each other. For example make the petal width equal to the wall_thickness, so even if you are asking for infill none will be generated.
A quick way to dial in your slicer settings VS petal widths is to use a calibration comb where each tooth is a different width and they cover a range of widths. Get one here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:239255
I also want a nice thick drooloop so I never print finer that 0.2mm layer height. If you want to use different settings look at the advance setting area when generating your model.
FOR MORE SYMMETRICAL FLOWERS - TURN FAN OFF ONCE THE PETALS START PRINTING. If you don't turn off the fan it will be okay - your flowers may have a wind-blown effect since the petals may drift in the direction of the fan (see "Makes" for windy flowers). If you want, you can turn off the fan by watching the printer and turning off the fan with your controller (if you have one), BUT my favorite method (since not all my printers have controllers, and I prefer to only constantly monitor my printers while the 1st layers are going down) is to quickly and simply modify the gcode file with a simple text editor. This way I can print a bunch and know it will always work. Using a basic text editor, open the gcode text file and make these changes:
  • Turn off the fans on the layer just before the petals start to print. I usually add a comment to the layer name like "mark turned off fans" and then add right below that:
    M106 S0
    M107
    This is kinda over kill, but i do it like that anyway. You can get the layer number needed by simple math:
    p_start_height/p_height=layer# petals start
    OR by using the layer viewer.
  • Search DOWN through the rest of the print looking for "M106" and just "comment out" those lines by adding a semicolon to the start of them...
    so when you see:
    M106 S58
    you make it say:
    ;M106 S58
    (Depending on your slicer, settings, model, etc..you may or may not find a lot of these fan speed commands. NOTE: Make sure the changes are in the "petal printing area", since a full-document search and replace may turn off the fan before you want it to.)
    here's a video that will help make this more clear:
    http://youtu.be/hYmclbTH7nw
    UPDATE TO VIDEO - for MakerBot people the gcode is different. see this video for important details when using a MakerBot printer
    http://youtu.be/xSOI1Sr6xIk

comments.text: If you are using Cura as your slicer, there is an easy way to turn the fan off at the desired height without manually editing your gcode. First. make sure that you are using "Switch to full settings..." on the "Expert" menu. Then determine the z height at which you want the fan to turn off. (You can use the "Layers" view mode to check this, once you set your layer height and initial layer thickness.) Then choose the "Tweak at Z" plug-in from the Plug-ins list. Enter the z height to tweak that you determined previously. Then enter 0 as your new fan speed.
comments.author: flaneur

comments.text: I am stumped, and this is very interesting, thanks for you post! I don't know much about the work flow for markerbots, so check with an expert...i know some of the people out there have used markerbots to print these. BUT here's what I tried, and what I think would be next steps......(I verified what you're seeing, neither of us are losing our minds) :-)   I changed my "machine setting" in CURA to be "makerbot replicator" (there is not option for R2), and I don't see any fan controls in the resulting gcode either. Some quick searching seems to show that the original makerbot did not have a fan?maybe? so...maybe CURA is not putting fan control in "makerbot flavored gcode" because it thinks there is no fan? some more reading revealed that makerbots don't run on gcode raw (like the open source printers do) it needs to be converted to the binary X3G using the makerware software...Soooo I'm wondering if the makeware software would accept the Cura "rep/rap (mariln/sprinter) flavor gcode" or if it would puke on that? I would try leaving your cura machine settings like they are for printer sizes etc, and just change to gcode flavor, maybe before you bother trying to control the fan with the text editor just see if the makerware software will accept the gcode or if it will error. that's all I can think of for now, probably need to read some more forum posts. I'm going to the Detroit maker faire this weekend maybe I find a makerbot owner and grill them on their work flow, maybe there's gcode import settings.

description.text: These are Atoms with electron configurations from Hydrogen to Boron. They contain the first two electron shells with the appropriate ground state electrons.

Atoms with the proper 3D arrangement for electrons with 1s, 2s, and 2p orbitals.

Please be aware that the p-orbitals (Boron) are difficult to print. If you are having difficulty then you may wish to use the 2D shell designs: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2401588

This is a medium duty battery post / terminal. "Proper" automotive terminals where too much money, and I don't need to provide that much power. The little bench supply terminals were too light duty. So I made these.

The "post" is a 3/16 inch threaded rod. The hole in the metal is 3/8". I happened to have a couple special threaded rods with 1/4" nut built into the middle. I glued a 5/16" nut into the caps to thread them on. They should cover the post to minimize moisture.

I have located the RV battery for our tent trailer inside (where the water tank used to be - we never used the sink), however, I still need/want a way to connect solar, accessories, chargers, etc to the battery. The wires on the hitch were loose and always a bit concerning. I printed these in red and black and installed them on our hitch.

Frankenbot

No

0.25mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Print it on the short edge and as soon as roundness printing is most risky place the model on the edge which when in use will be also on the bottom.
Supports are just needed so that you get smooth internal surface of the upper edge.
Also use two shells to get less wrapping when printing the lower roundness.
Better to print from ABS or other higher temperature resistant resin as usually these parts are exposed to sunlight.

title: Anet A8 S-240-12 Power Supply Cover

description.text:
This is a cover for the power supply supplied with the Anet A8 Part No. S-240-12

The Sketch up drawing can be modified to suit what ever IEC connection and switch you have on hand.

The triangular prism brim around the cover is to limit any warping and lifting of the sides off the platform that some printers have issues with. Cut it off before installation.

The cover has two mounting holes, one in the side and another in the front. Remove the screw next to the power supplies terminal strip and replace with a new screw with a slightly smaller head diameter. I used a spare screw that came with the Anet A8 cut down to 6.5mm thread length.

I recommend you install a cover on your power supply as the first mod you do as it does not comply with any safety standards the way it is.

ChipERemix

Another Chip-E remix idea. I was playing with my Syma QuadCopter and thought it would be a cool idea to turn the Chip-E robot into a flying machine. Its not designed to fly Chip-E around like a quad copter would; but more get him around obstacles. I the copter is probably not strong enough to move him around to much for to long

NEXT:
The next thing I want to make is an all-In-one controller for both the quadcopter and chip-E bot.

title: Crabby Cap Zesty Nimble SeeMeCNC HE280/Accelerometer Mount

description.text:
Update 18 Aug 2017: System has been working well. Have put about two rolls of filament (Ninjaflex, PETG, ABS and a little PLA) through it without any problems or jams. The Nimble seems to hold the PTFE tube firmly in the bottom of the barrel (PTC is loose).
Printing without a Bowden tube is a whole new world!!!

For more detail (with photos) on installation see the Nimble Adapter section of the Prometheus variant of this adapter

Note: - this is a prototype. I have only put a little NinjaFlex through it so there are likely to be changes over the next couple of weeks but so far, so good...

Crabby Cap is an adapter to mount the Zesty Nimble Direct Drive Extruder on the SeeMeCNC HE280 (see also Turpinator's solution) for SeeMeCNC Accelerometer Plate equipped with fan headers and plugs.

Required Parts and Tools:

  • 3 of M3x16 to 20mm Bolts are used to mount the cap
  • 3mm or 1/8" drill to size cap mounting holes
  • 2.4mm or 3/32" drill to size Nimble mounting holes prior to tapping
  • M3x0.5 Tap to tap Nimble mounting holes
  • ~ 60mm 4mmOD x 1.8 to 2.0mmID PTFE tubing
  • Drill bit (4mm+/-) to slightly oversize Guide Bushing bore to suit your PTFE tube size
  • A half inch or similar half round file for finishing and sizing
  • Sharp knife or razor to trim PTFE tubing
  • Metal Saw to cut M3 Bolt
  • Method of measuring hot end barrel depth

Instructions:

  • Cap best printed upside down. Recommend PETG. Size centre hole to 16mm. Size cap retention holes to 3mm. Size the two Nimble mounting holes to 2.4mm and tap.
  • Guide Bushing should have a total length of 9mm. Smaller diameter 8.5mm, larger diameter just under 16mm. ABS recommended.
  • Straps can be printed in Ninjaflex after you get your new direct drive extruder up and running!
  • Trim ONE of the 40mm bolts that come with the Nimble to 35-37mm.
  • Trim any soldered wires and ensure the fan wiring is arranged to be less than 2.5mm above the board.
  • Ensure that the Guide Bushing passes freely through the centre hole of the cap
  • Square one end of the PTFE tube and chamfer the OD slightly.
  • Drill out the bore of the guide bushing so that your PTFE tube passes smoothly through it
  • Measure the depth of the barrel in the hot end and the length of the PTFE tube.
  • Insert the squared and tapered end of the PTFE tube into the hot end barrel and seat it firmly.
  • Measure amount of PTFE tube protruding and verify tube is fully seated in the bottom of the hotend barrel.
  • Install the cap with the M3x16-20mm bolts. They will self tap.
  • Place the Guide Bushing over the PTFE tubing and seat it on top of the hot end.
  • Trim the PTFE tubing so that it just slightly protrudes above the top of the Guide Bushing (0.3mm or about the width of a razor blade).
  • Place the Nimble Groove Mount Adapter over the Guide Bushing, it should lay flat against the cap top, shorten Guide Bushing if necessary.
  • Mount the Nimble. Use the 40mm bolt with the Sleeve Clamp (or a 3mm spacer for fit testing without the drive cable) to avoid damaging the board.
  • Gentle tightening of the extruder bolts should cause the Nimble to seat squarely on the Groove Mount Adapter and the PTFE tube should contact the bottom of the filament guide on centre without distortion. Re-trim the PTFE tube if necessary.

This is a simple open case designed to be used with the Black Magic Probe v2.1 by 1BitSquared. (https://1bitsquared.com/products/black-magic-probe). This version of the case is flat for easier access to the JTAG connector.

There are small tabs that hold the corners of the circuit board in place. Tilt the board and insert the USB-connector end of the board into the closed end of the case first. Then slide the other end down, spreading the sides of the case apart as needed until the board snaps in place under the tabs. Of course, be extremely careful not to put pressure on any components on the board!

description.text: Holder deigned for MiBand watchband (1 and 2). May can be used in other wristwatch models.

print_settings.Notes:: There are two shallow indents on the model, this is to glue a small rubber strip there to increase the friction between the model and the wall. If printed to correct wall size and glued rubber strips the model should hold onto the wall without anyone holding it up making it easy to install gate with the model.
print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
Created this model because my current gate was damaging the wall causing dents and that each time a child would shake or lean against the gate it would fall down essentially rendering the purpose of the gate useless.

This is a custom model and may not work with your gate / wall. I have provided a small diagram showing the important sizes of the model. You might have to alter the stl to suite your own situation.

Edit: 1 July 2017 -- Added a gate holder for square edges if your wall is not rounded. Again the width of the model may not be the same as your wall so some tweaking of the model may be required.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Use triangle support;
The 5 cylinders with the triangle support spread the pressure throughout the contact area of the model and the wall protecting the wall from the force exerted by the gate. The square expanded section is to help in spreading forces across a wider area using the triangle support.

There are two shallow indents on the model, this is to glue a small rubber strip there to increase the friction between the model and the wall. If printed to correct wall size and glued rubber strips the model should hold onto the wall without anyone holding it up making it easy to install gate with the model.

author: loserkid418

title: Andonstar USB microscope mount for Liteplacer Pick and place (SHAT1220)

description.text:
This is a mod for the Liteplacer pick and place kit.

This adapter lets you replace the original downward facing camera with a Andonstar V160 USB microscope. The original downward facing camera has a larger diameter than the andonstar.

I saw that the Apertus wiki (https://wiki.apertus.org/index.php/Liteplacer_PnP_Machine_Notes) recommended the Misumi SHAT1220, but I wasn't a fan of the dimensions (a bit too thin imho) or the price (Approx $25+S&H).

I modeled this using the critical dimensions of the SHAT1220, but increased the height a bit for a bit better alignment.

Note! Right now the design is tentative since my liteplacer hasn't shown up yet. If you can think of changes it needs, let me know!

The teardrop holes let me print it out easily without cleaning out the holes so the bolts just slip right in.

UPDATE! I got the liteplacer kit set up, one of the Z rollers interferes with the original mount. I uploaded a new model that shortens the height and works properly. This is the "fakeSHAT1220deux.stl" file.

Many Thanks to- Mr Gael- Inmoov’s Designer

These are the Bicep Frames Converted to .Dwg Format- for CNC/Laser Cuting there are all 7.5mm Thick but 7mm or 8mm “should” work fine,,,

For the 2 Stage Potentiometer Hole on the Bicep frame I have removed the 13.5mm Dia hole and just kept the 5mm Potentiometer shaft hole (used as a pilot hole),,,,, then you can just use a drillpress to drill it out to the size of your Potentiometer----- the original hole is 13.5mm Dia and is 5.7 mm deep,,,, and is actually a 3 stage hole with second stage having a notch taken out to stop the Potentiometer from spinning out of position (see pic)-
I also made the x2 screw holes on the sides of Potentiometer hole go all the way through to the otherside--

People use all different sort/sizes of Potentiometer and modify that spot to suit their Potentiometer--- other than that everything else should be pretty easy—iv used the original parts from Mr Gael and not modified ones,,, all I’ve done is join the 2x Bicep frames together (which was a Perfect fit) to make the one part –

The Bicep Frames are the same for both sides of the Bicep -&- for both Left and Right arm,,, so you only need the one file-- but have done both sides just in case the material you are using has a different Topside finish to the Bottom Side finish--

Note*-- I do not have a CNC/Laser Cutter and these files where done by request – there are the original STL converted to DWG – --and -Mr Gael- designed them 3d Printing not CNC/Laser Cutting so there will be problems as dictated by “Murph’s Law”

-=Mindless=-

print_settings.Notes:: I used .98 extrusion multiplier on eSun PETG. Seems to work well.

description.text:
The "Snake Bite" bed clip holds the CR-10 glass bed in place while printing. The clip extends along the underside of the bed so you can slip a piece of cork or other insulating material under the aluminum bed. You'll want at least 2 just for the glass. 3 or more if you're going to use an insulator underneath also.

Installation

To install, turn it sideways and slip between the underside of the bed and the Y plate.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

40% or less

Notes:

Don't forget to turn the model diagonally on your bed for printing.

Material

I used PETG for this piece. I have not tried other materials yet. Nylon should also work, or anything else that can take the bed heat. Due to the bed being heated, regular PLA may deform after a while without annealing. I'm not sure of the flexibility of annealed PLA. Again, I have not tested PLA, just my guess.

The part needs to be a little springy so you can install it. Keep that in mind when choosing material and percent of infill. ABS ins't terribly stretchy, so I didn't even try it.

Speeds

Printing at speed 40 or less will keep the layer adhesion very good. Faster prints were more "crunchy" with bad layer adhesion. I haven't tried smaller layer heights, but feel free to experiment.

Since this is a thin part, keep an eye on the ends about mid print. One or both ends came off the build plate after about half way through. Kapton tape works well. Make sure to clean it with alcohol between prints to keep it grippy.

Temperatures

PETG settings for printing were 245C to start and 243C after the third layer. I used bed heat of 70C throughought.

Fill

I sliced with Slic3r with 40% rectilinear fill and concentric top layer. Speed 45mm/s and 25mm/s for small perimeters.

I used .98 extrusion multiplier on eSun PETG. Seems to work well.

Designed in Inkscape and then coverted to STL with Tinkercad.

I designed the shape in 2D with Inkscape. After I had the style I wanted, I imported the .SVG into Tinkercad, the online 3D editor. FYI, the SVG preview is not the full image. I'm not sure why it doesn't display here. If you download the file and open in Inkscape you should be able to edit the nodes. No guarantees if opening in Illustrator. Illustrator does not always import SVG correctly.

I noticed the size was wrong after import to Tinkercad. The imported file read as 333mm long. I updated to 313mm and immediately exported to .stl.
This is the 313x10 on the STL file. There's about 6mm per side of width beyond the 300mm bed size for the outer edge of the clip.

Test fit the clip before running a print with it installed. The tolerance is very narrow. The left side seems to be closer to the tower than the right, at least on my machine.

Or just install front to back instead of left to right like me. The bed is symetric so it shouldn't really matter. There's a lot of room under there. I'm thinking of adding a shelf, a lamp and maybe an alarm clock so I can have a nap.

title: Machi Koro to Machi Koro: Bright Lights, Big City Conversion Compact (Expansion) Box Insert

description.text:
Machi Koro: Bright Lights, Big City is in my opinion the ultimate version of Machi Koro, but in practice it is only a repack of most of the base game and the Harbor and Millionaire's row expansions, with a slightly altered rule set. Because I already own the base game and both expansions, and since I also keep the game in the handily sized expansion box, I figured a nice insert for the converted game in an expansion box would come in handy.

Convert the game by removing cards according to this BGG wiki entry. For 100% conversion you need to substitute the Dice Tower promo card for the Moon Tower; but the game plays fine (some would argue better) without it. In the latter case, either leave it out or keep the Radio Tower from the base game.

Print one each of the two card trays and the dice tray, but two coin trays that stack on top of each other. They all fit together perfectly as shown in the pictures, with a compartment below the dice tray for keeping the extra cards not used in the conversion (which would be heresy to throw away). Included is also a rack to keep the dice I use (4 discarded casino dice in addition to the 2 included ones) from wobbling around in the box.

I've printed after scaling it 400%. But you can scale it as you want. I usually print using slic3r, but it was taking ages to slice this model. So I recommend use Craftware (or maybe Cura - I didn't tried on this) to print this model.

NOTE: This model is segmented! The .stl that has the full Tower is not meant to be printed, is for preview only.

author: doitverything

title: Pokeball, with magnetic clasp and release mechanism

description.text:
I wanted to make this Pokéball with magnetic casp https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:420782
but I also wanted to be able to really press the button and make some kind of release happen, so I edited it. You will need a spring (from a pen or a battery pack) and some strong glue to assemble it (I've coated the base of the spring with epoxy and glued everything that needed to be glued using super glue and epoxy). In the pictures I had to use a bigger magnet since I did not have small ones, so I enlarged the holes with a dremmel. Just to let you know it's possible. The only parts that do NOT have to be glued are the bottom half, the pin and the internal part of the white button.

I've also swapped the top and the bottom since the black ring is supposed to stay with the top red part (both in the original anime and in the latest games, Sun and Moon).

I've also made the inside of the Pokéball round, just print it with supports or have faith in your overhangs.

Included the stand from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1509923

print_settings.Printer:: Felix 3.1 Dual Head (only one head used)

description.text:
This is my ultimate Filament Spool Holder ;-)

Remark: Only the Filament Spool Holder is my design. All other parts in the photographs are only for illustration and are not designed by me. But I don't remember the sources. If one feels that I should reference his/her design please let me know and I will be glad to add the reference.

I have tried many different solutions to hold my filament spools. All had some benefits and also disadvantages. So I designed this one myself. It is very strong, uses a 200 mm long M8 threaded rod, a M8 lock nut, two M6 screws and two M6 t-slot nuts to be attached to the t-slot of my Felix 3.1 printer. Since it has a flat mounting surface it can also be attached to many other printers/positions including a wall. Just use the relevant screws.

On the M8 rod there can be used many available adapters and attachments as can be seen on the other pictures which show some of my examples. These parts only need to have a inner diameter of 8mm (+) which also applies to often used 608 bearings.

For those who want to modify the holder, I have included the 123D Design 123dx file

Update 1: The blue holder part in pictures 5, 6 and 7 is from here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2075777

Update 2: The "Quick change filament spool clips" could be used in combination with my design to change spools very fast (credits go to the origin designer):
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2470943

Update 3: Can be used with https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2565565/#comments to get a more or less universal spool holder.

Printer:

Felix 3.1 Dual Head (only one head used)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

60 %

Notes:

additional parts used:

M8 threaded rod 200 mm long
M8 lock nut
2 x screw M6 x 18
2 x nuts M6 in printed t-slot nut holder

designed with 123D Design which is still available but not supported anymore

I should also mention that the hole for the rod is a bit smaller than 8 mm because I cut a thread with a 8mm screw tap. This makes the complete part stronger. Alternative you could just drill it with a 8.1+ drill or with an 8.0 mm drill and ream it a bit

title: Fidget spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Made a fidget spinner with washers and bolts as weight, instead of bearings. This way will save you the use of 3 bearings.

The bolts are M4x8 mm, and the nut is a square M4.
The washers are Ø18 mm.
Bearing: ABEC-7 608 rs, all 608 bearings should fit.

Print setup:

Material: Innofill PLA silver (all "hard" materials should be fine)
Heat nozzle: First layer; 205 C , afterwards 200 C
Heat bed: non
Nozzle size: 0,3
Layer height: 0,15
Support under each "washer space", if your printer is good at bridging it should be possible without support.

comments.text:
Interesting! After I printed your Mikro SD Wallet I was thinking of a solution to include the SD adapter. Now you are coming with this design :-)
I have an other idea which I would like to show you by a photograph. But that's not possible to add here. So I will post it in my "I made one" of your wallet posting.
My suggestion is to rotate the slots for the Mikro SD Cards by 90 ° narrow the space in between (this could make room for 10 cards or 2 times 10 cards if you put two in a slot, plus the adapter). If there is no need for the adapter, it could then be used for a normal SD card.

comments.text: I didn't put the adapter in the tray because it would have required me to make the wallet thicker, but I can attach the source file, if you want to try remixing it!

Notes:

For those who want to make some changes to the thing:

  1. After making changes to the Sketch, remove the original Fusion.
  2. Switch to the "Draft" workbench to make an Array of the Pad (Array type: polar, Number XYZ: 1, Number Polar: 2 or more).
  3. Select the Pad and Make Draft->Downgrade two times (you'll get Compound first, then multiple Solids)!
  4. Switch to the "Part" workbench, select all solids and make Fusion (Part->Boolean->Union).
    Ignore some overlaps as the model will be fine after the export.
  5. Export to STL.
    Done with FreeCAD 0.16.

title: Wall Spot Lamp cnc/laser
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This tiltable wall spot lamp is intended to be used with a GU10 socket and mounted
vertical, over a mirror in a bathroom for example. Even with ventilation openings using a classic halogen bulb might not be the best of all ideas, you should resort to a modern LED bulb. I got the ceramic socket from a hardware store for a few bucks. The cable were long enough to feed them through the foot.

This build was done from 6.3 mm beech plywood using a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft with a 1.2 mm spiral toothed end mill. A vacuum machine bed simplifies the process significantly, because you don't need to camp the material, thus it stays pretty flat. Further more I don't need tabs on the parts resulting in less sanding.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs. Consider a donation if you like the build.

Keep in mind that the stl-file is for three dimensional viewing purpose only. It will not print on an FDM printer.

comments.text: Very nicely done.

title: Tamron Adaptall 2 2x SP Teleconverter Tripod Ring with RC2 QR Plate

description.text:
This is a Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2277236 with a 65.4mm diameter so may fit other lenses of close to that size.

As well as the default customized design, I have gone further and also added a version that integrates a Manrotto RC2 Quick Release Plate that will mount directly onto a compatible tripod head.

The test version picture is printed in PLA but I would strongly recommend PETG or ABS for additional strength. Pictured is a Fujifilm XT-20 with adaptor, teleconverter and Tamron Adaptall 2 200mm F3.5 lens. This combination feels extremely stable and balances well.

The 'bolt' in one of the pictures is actually part of a wall mount for JBL Control 1 speakers - fits nicely!

This is a Stratux Case designed to directly mount the RY836 to the top. It is designed for a Raspberry Pi 2. The Power and Activity LEDs are in a different place for the RPi3. Update: I have added versions for the RPi3 but they are untested.

Update#2: I have revised the design based on feedback. First, the case a little taller, to give extra space for a female Dupont connector and cable routing. Also, I extended the hex features for the adapters, to account for variations in the size of the SDRs and adapters. (minor update in v2.1 of top case to fix interference with the corner peg)

I have not printed it, as the case I use has a different internal configuration.

Fan is a 25mm x 7mm fan. 5v.

The screws that hold the case together are #3-48. -- not sure which screws to use to hold the GPS to the top.

The holes for the LEDs should be reamed with a drill bit slightly smaller than 1.75mm, then force fit some tGlase filament in and trim to size. (as long as the ends are cut square and smooth, tGlase make a great fiber optic light pipe)

This was designed for two NooElec NESDR Nano 2's. I removed the IR receivers and installed heat sinks. You have to cut the heat sinks down so that they don't short any components.

If you install heat sinks, you'll have a hard time installing a WiFi dongle. I made a little 4" USB extension with a very slim connector (PCB) to place the wifi dongle in the area in front of the Ethernet port.

The MCX SMA adapters were bought on eBay in December of 2015. I'm sure they make different ones, so it might be hard to source the exact ones I used. The ones I bought were on eBay under the title "SMA Female to MCX Male Adapter Connector; US Stock ; Fast Shipping". There are still ones being sold with that title, so maybe they're the same? Your mileage my vary. I do not endorse the sellers on eBay.

Glare shield mat is intended to be printed in NinjaFlex or some other grippy flexible filament. (NinjaFlex is not super grippy, but it works). I printed this in Simplify3D with zero bottom solid layers and a honeycomb fill to make a nice pattern on the bottom.

You can find the full CAD model on OnShape: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/8c34c1c767a49570ccc6db5e/w/93531f10fb86484c55d0aeb6/e/32c82b0e1dffe52a88c88737

print_settings.Notes:: Petg at 237 C, bed at 60 C

description.text:
Create a waterreservoir by widening the outer diameter of your drainpipe and inserting a inner pipe to create an overflow.
This design is 125mm outer diameter and has a 50 mm inner pipe, The normal diameter of my drainpipe is 80 mm
Total length is 2.25 m which creates a watervolume of ( 0,0625^2 X 3.141 x 2.25 ) - ( 0.025^2 3.141 2.25 ) equals 23.2 liters.
I used the thread of Thread

Printer:

Beagle standard

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Petg at 237 C, bed at 60 C

Use your existing pipe to fit all pieces together. You will have to cut a piece off for the bottom section and a piece for the top section.
I used PVC glue for fixing everything together and silicone kit to make everything watertight.
I used 123d for design

Bill of materials

1 pvc drainpipe 125mm diameter 2.25 m long
1 pvc pip 50 mm diameter 2.25 m long
2 wall mounts for the 125mm pipe. maybe 3 to support the 30kg for a completely filled reservoir
pvc glue
silicone kit

title: The Rabbit In the Hat Trick

description.text: This is a work in progress and a future iteration will attempt to scan the Bunny to nothing. This iteration will be printed in an signed edition of 10, it is currently exhibited at Firecat Projects in Chicago [ http://www.firecatprojects.org/ ] and will also be available from Fuse Works [ http://www.fuse-works.com/ ]. http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2lgDLrDeeWk&feature=youtu.be

A 3D model of the Stanford Bunny published by Makerbot ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:88208 ) on Thingiverse is printed and scanned on the Makerbot Digitizer. The resulting 3D scan is in turn printed and scanned. This process is repeated until the Bunny begins to disappear.
